Triggering Event: Dr. A wakes up to find her partner's side of the bed empty, their phone missing from the nightstand. She looks at hers; no messages, no calls. Anxiety begins to stir, a familiar gnawing feeling. She checks the kitchen, living room, bathroom - nothing. The clock reads 6:30 AM. They're never up this early without her. She texts tentatively, "Hey, everything ok?" No immediate reply. Twenty minutes later, she hears the front door open. Her partner walks in with a bag from their favorite bakery, grinning, oblivious to the worried silence that hung heavy in their absence.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, I'm so fucking frustrated right now. I can't believe he just left like that. I was already stressed about work today, and then I wake up to an empty bed, no phone, no message. I feel like shit. He's probably out there getting his breakfast somewhere, but what if it's more? What if he’s gone for good? I know I’m overreacting, but I can't help how I feel. It feels like he's abandoned me again. We had such great conversations last night, but maybe it was all just an illusion. Now I'm alone in my apartment, wondering if he'll ever come back. This is ridiculous; I shouldn't be feeling this way. But I can't shake off these thoughts. I keep thinking about all the times he has left me, and I wonder why I even bother anymore. It's stupid to think he might have left, isn't it? But the thought keeps popping into my head. Maybe he does have another woman, maybe he doesn't want me anymore. I can't stand it; I need him to reassure me. Why would he leave like this? I know he loves me, but sometimes I doubt it. Is this really happening? Shouldn't I be happy we're together? How could I be so silly? He must still be sleeping, or he wouldn't be here right now. I hope he wasn't with someone else. That would make me look like a fool

Triggering Event: A software engineer, late 60s, received an email from his former team. They had started working with someone younger and more "agile" for their latest project, leaving him feeling redundant. He sighed, staring at the familiar faces in the group photo, now excluding him.
Generated Assessment: Ugh... I can't believe it. Everyone's moved on already. Look at this stupid fucking photo - they're all smiling like fools while my face is just there, looking awkward. It doesn't even look like me; they've Photoshopped out everything that makes me recognizable. That poor kid, he must think we're a bunch of dinosaurs, but what does he know? We were the best team back then. Now, I'm stuck with nothing but outdated code. What's the point? I'll be lucky if I get a meeting with them. That little prick has no idea how much work went into those projects. Do these people remember anything? This is so unfair. I was always the smartest one on the team, the one who knew everything. But no, everyone's forgotten about me. The emails are just confirmation of what I already know - I'm useless now. Why did they have to send this stupid photo? Did they want to rub it in? I hate this shit. What am I going to do now? My career is over. This is all because of that new kid. If only I could go back to when things made sense... Why do I keep getting reminders about things I don't want to remember? Can't they see I'm trying to forget? Ugh, why did I let myself get involved in this again?

The emptiness of their usual spot seemed to yawn wider as she held the sweater to her face, inhaling his scent that was slowly fading away.

Triggering Event: A man in his 50s, a doctor by profession and widowed for several years, finds himself standing over a patient's chart. The familiar handwriting of his late wife, now deceased for five years, stares back at him from the notes section. His grip tightens on the pen, knuckles turning white as he realizes this was her last case before she fell ill. He imagines the man who took her life walking free, and a cold vengeance seeps into his veins.

Just get your head out of those fucked up scenarios and focus on the present. But damn, what if... Ugh, you need to snap the fuck out of it. This isn't helping anyone. Get over it already. It's been five years; time is running out for all of us. Stop wasting your energy on "what ifs" and let go. Now, please, for the love of God, stop asking yourself these ridiculous questions. Triggering Event: In the quiet of her apartment, she finds an unopened envelope addressed in her ex-husband's handwriting, tucked behind her bookshelf where it had fallen out of sight during their hurried divorce proceedings.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I am so fucking pissed off right now. It's like he just left me with this huge "fuck you" note that I can't even read because I'm still fuming about how he did me dirty. He was supposed to give me all his stuff back after our divorce, but noooo...he didn't even bother to tell me. Like what kind of asshole does that? He's literally trying to make it look like we were never married, which is such a dick move. The fact that he would leave me a note without telling me makes me think he doesn't care about me at all; maybe he wants to make it seem like I never existed to him. I swear, he must be doing this to spite me. This is just another way for him to screw me over and make me feel worse than ever. ## Step 1: Identify the trigger She found an unopened envelope from her ex-husband, triggering strong emotions. ## Step 2: Analyze the thoughts Her initial reaction is anger, thinking her ex-husband intentionally left her a note without telling her, implying he might want to "make her feel worse." Triggering Event: At 5 pm, she arrives home to find her partner's suitcase by the door and a note saying they needed some space.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, I'm so upset! He just left me at the airport, and I didn't even get a chance to say goodbye. I feel like he abandoned me, but then again, he said we needed space? What does that even mean? Is this his way of telling me he doesn't love me anymore? That he wants to be with someone else? Or is it because he can't handle my anxiety? This isn't fair; he knows how much stress I go through. Now I'll have to deal with all this alone. It's not fair he gets to leave whenever he feels stressed, while I stay here and take care of everything. How am I supposed to cope when he just disappears like this? Why did he leave now? Did something happen between him and his friends? Maybe he's still hungover from last night's party. I know he was drinking, but why would that make him leave me? Does he think I don't know what happened? Doesn't he realize I've been dealing with all these things for months already? And now he leaves me with nothing but a note about needing space? Are you kidding me? Space? He doesn't need space, he needs therapy. We were happy until he started getting distant. I thought we had talked about it, but maybe I was wrong. Maybe he didn't want to talk about it because he felt overwhelmed. But why did he just leave? Did he plan this? Was there another woman involved?

Triggering Event: While making rounds at Sunnybrook Hospital, she found her former partner's name still printed on the whiteboard, despite his retirement years ago. A small thing, but it rankled, fueling her irritation.
Generated Assessment: I can’t believe that he’s still listed there. I mean, what if he gets called back to work? What if he comes up with some new idea that needs him to be there? I’ve seen it happen before – people are always coming out of retirement for one project or another. It could happen again! And then they’ll have to go back to work, and we’ll all be stuck with them around again. The thought makes me anxious. I’m already stressed about the workload; adding someone else into the mix will just make things worse. But what if...? I don’t know why this bothers me so much. It’s probably just my imagination running wild. Still, I find myself thinking about it more often than usual. Maybe I’m just paranoid. Still, what if...? # Response End ## Step 1: Identify the Trigger The trigger is finding her former partner's name on the whiteboard at Sunnybrook Hospital. ## Step 2: Generate Subjective Reaction Using the "What if?" question, create a subjective reaction that reflects the cognitive distortion "What if?" without explicitly stating it. Triggering Event: In the chill of the evening, he walked alone through the park where they'd scattered her ashes. His badge weighed heavy in his pocket, each step echoing with memories of patrols together. He paused by their old bench, now weathered and worn like him. A young couple sat there, laughing, untouched by loss. His breath caught, not from the exertion, but from the sudden ache that felt like a fist around his heart. Their laughter rang hollow, a stark reminder of what he'd lost. He turned away, leaving them to their joy while he carried his grief home alone.
Generated Assessment: He stood frozen at the park's edge, the fading light casting long shadows across the grass. The air was filled with the sweet scent of blooming flowers, yet it brought no solace. The sound of children playing nearby seemed cruelly distant, as if deliberately muffled by some unseen force. The rustle of leaves beneath his feet served as a harsh reminder that time continued its relentless march, leaving nothing but memories behind. Every step felt like a betrayal, a rejection of the life he once knew. The pain he thought he’d buried was now exposed, like an open wound, refusing to heal. He could feel the weight of his badge, a constant reminder of his failure. It pressed against his leg, a physical manifestation of the emptiness within—empty promises, empty lives, and empty hopes. As night began to fall, the stars above seemed to mock him, their silence deafening. The world moved forward, oblivious to his suffering, while he was left to bear the burden of his mistakes alone. The cold wind whipped through his hair, a harsh breeze that echoed the turmoil brewing inside. Each breath felt like a struggle, as if the very act of living had become a chore. The darkness deepened, and with it, the sense of isolation. No one else understood what he went through; they couldn’t share his burden, nor did they need to. The world kept turning, indifferent to his pain, and he was left to carry the weight of his own guilt
